intro: Agalinis tenuifolia var. macrophylla, commonly known as the large-leaf false nettle, is a perennial herb native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes parasitic and hemiparasitic plants. The plant is characterized by its slender, erect stems and opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often hairy. Its flowers are small, tubular, and typically pink or purple, arranged in clusters at the ends of the branches. The species is adapted to moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands and along stream banks.
